identificationModule.briefTitle: Can the Origin of Sperm Affect Embryo Ploidy in Patients With Severe Male Factor Infertility?
identificationModule.officialTitle: Can the Origin of Sperm - Ejaculated or Testicular- Affect Embryo Ploidy in Patients With Severe Male Factor Infertility?

descriptionModule.briefSummary: There is evidence indicating that sperm plays a role in determining blastocyst ploidy status. In our study, we aim to compare the outcomes of preimplantation genetic testing for aneuploidy (PGT-A) and the subsequent clinical outcomes following transfers of euploid embryos. This comparison will be conducted between cases where ejaculated sperm and cases where testicular sperm were used for intracytoplasmic sperm injection (ICSI), specifically focusing on severe male factor infertility patients.

armGroups.label: Ejaculate
armGroups.description: Patients within this arm will undergo ICSI utilizing ejaculated sperm.

armGroups.label: Testicular
armGroups.description: Patients within this arm will undergo ICSI utilizing testicular sperm.

interventions.name: Testicular sperm extraction (TESE)
interventions.description: Surgical procedure used to retrieve sperm directly from the testicles of men who have low sperm production or no sperm in their ejaculate

primaryOutcomes.description: Defined as the proportion of euploid blastocysts
Defined as the proportion of aneuploid blastocysts
Defined as the proportion of low mosaic blastocysts
Defined as the proportion of high mosaic blastocysts
defined as the presence of a fetal heartbeat or gestational sac 6-9 weeks post-embryo transfer
defined as the percentage of successfully implanted embryos
defined as a positive heartbeat on ultrasound beyond 12 weeks of gestation
defined as pregnancy loss following confirmation of clinical pregnancy

secondaryOutcomes.description: Defined as the proportion of fertilizaed oocytes
Defined as the proportion of cleaved embryos on day 3
Defined as the proportion of blastocysts formed on day 5 or 6

eligibilityModule.eligibilityCriteria:
Inclusion Criteria:

* Cases planned to have ICSI PGT-A cycles
* Males diagnosed as severe male factor infertility
* Normo responder female partners

Exclusion Criteria:

* Leukocytospermia
* Presence of varicocele.
* Known genetic abnormality
* Use of sperm or oocyte donors
* Use of gestational carrier
* Presence of any of the endometrial factors that affect embryo implantation such as hydrosalpings, adenomyosis or previous uterine infection
* Any contradictions to undergoing in vitro fertilization or gonadotropin stimulation

browseBranches.name: Urinary Tract, Sexual Organs, and Pregnancy Conditions
